section.title: Working with Cartesian Unit Vectors

introduction.title: Unit Vectors Along Cartesian Positive Axis Directions

p.p: Unit vectors along Cartesian axes play important role in vector analysis. We will often denote these unit vectors by \hat u_x , \hat u_y , and \hat u_z respectively. At other times, we will denote them by their traditional symbols \hat i , \hat j , and \hat k respectively.

sidebyside.p:
For instance, say, we want a position vector \vec r = ( x=2 \text{ m}, y=-5 \text{ m}) in the xy-plane. Then, you can see that this vector will be a sum of two vectors: \vec r_1 = 2 \text{ m} \hat i and \vec r_2 = -5 \text{ m} \hat j . We write this as
\vec r = 2 \text{ m} \hat i - 5 \text{ m} \hat j.

introduction.p:
In general, an arbitrary vector \vec A with coordinate components A_x, A_y, A_z is often written as a sum of vectors along the Cartesian axes.
\vec A = A_x \hat i + A_y \hat j + A_z \hat k.

section.subsection:
Dot and Cross Products of Cartesian Unit Vectors
Since \hat i, \hat j, and \hat k, has unit magnitude, and are perpendicular to each other, we get the following dot and cross products.
\text{Dot products: }\amp\hat i \cdot \hat i = 1,\ \ \hat j \cdot \hat j = 1,\ \ \hat k \cdot \hat k = 1, \amp \hat i \cdot \hat j = 0,\ \ \hat j \cdot \hat k = 0,\ \ \hat k \cdot \hat i = 0, \text{Cross products: }\amp\hat i \times \hat i = 0,\ \ \hat j \times \hat j = 0,\ \ \hat k \times \hat k = 0, \amp \hat i \times \hat j = \hat k,\ \ \hat j \times \hat k = \hat i,\ \ \hat k \times \hat k = \hat j,
With these, you can easily see how the components of an arbitrary vector \vec A = \left( A_x, A_y, A_z\right) are just the dot product of \vec A with the unit vectors along the axex.
A_x = \vec A \cdot \hat i,\ \ A_y = \vec A \cdot \hat j,\ \ A_z = \vec A \cdot \hat k.
The magnitude of \vec A is same as before
A = \sqrt{\vec A \cdot \vec A} = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2}.
Cosines of the angles \vec A makes with positive axes, called direction cosines of the vector, are
\cos\,\theta_x = \dfrac{A_x}{A},\ \ \cos\,\theta_y = \dfrac{A_y}{A},\ \ \cos\,\theta_z = \dfrac{A_z}{A},
of which you only need two to denote direction of \vec A since
\cos^2\theta_x + \cos^2\theta_y + \cos^2\theta_z = 1.
Angles for direction cosines.
Proof: It is easy to prove relation between direction cosines.
\cos^2\theta_x \amp + \cos^2\theta_y + \cos^2\theta_z
\amp = \left( \frac{A_x}{A} \right)^2 + \left( \frac{A_y}{A} \right)^2 + \left( \frac{A_z}{A} \right)^2 \amp = \frac{A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2}{A^2} = \frac{A^2}{A^2} = 1.
Dot Product of Two Vectors Using Cartesian Unit Vectors: A dot product of two vectors is rather simple to obtain from their Cartesian components. Let
\vec A = A_x \hat i + A_y \hat j + A_z \hat k,\ \ \vec B = B_x \hat i + B_y \hat j + B_z \hat k.
Then, we will havbe
\vec A \cdot \vec B \amp = (A_x \hat i + A_y \hat j + A_z \hat k) \cdot (B_x \hat i + B_y \hat j + B_z \hat k) \amp = A_x B_x (\hat i \cdot \hat i) + A_x B_y (\hat i \cdot \hat j) + A_x B_z (\hat i \cdot + \hat k) + \cdots \amp = A_x B_x (1) + A_x B_y (0) + A_x B_z (0) + \cdots \amp = A_x B_x + A_y B_y + A_z B_z.
Of course this will equal A B \cos\theta with angle \theta between the two vectors.
\vec A \cdot \vec B = A B \cos\theta = A_x B_x + A_y B_y + A_z B_z.
Cross Product of Two Vectors Using Cartesian Unit Vectors: I have already given formulas for this above.
\vec A \times \vec B = \left(A_y B_z - A_z B_y\right) \hat i + \left(A_z B_x - A_x B_z\right) \hat j + \left(A_x B_y - A_y B_x\right) \hat k.
We can show this to be the case now by expicitly working out the cross product.
\vec A \times \vec B \amp = (A_x \hat i + A_y \hat j + A_z \hat k) \times (B_x \hat i + B_y \hat j + B_z \hat k) \amp = A_x B_x (\hat i \times \hat i) + A_x B_y (\hat i \times \hat j) + A_x B_z (\hat i \times + \hat k) + \cdots \amp = A_x B_x (0) + A_x B_y (\hat k) + A_x B_z (- \hat j) + \cdots \amp = [A_x B_y (\hat k) + A_x B_z (- \hat j)] + [A_y B_x (-\hat k) + A_y B_z (\hat i)] \amp \ \ \ \ \ \ + [A_z B_x (\hat j) + A_z B_y (-\hat i)] \amp = \left(A_y B_z - A_z B_y\right) \hat i + \left(A_z B_x - A_x B_z\right) \hat j + \left(A_x B_y - A_y B_x\right) \hat k.
Often, we express this result in the form of a determinant.
\vec A \times \vec B = \begin{vmatrix} \hat i \amp \hat j \amp \hat k \\ A_x \amp A_y \amp A_z \\ B_x \amp B_y \amp B_z \\ \end{vmatrix}

exercise.title: Practice with Dot Product of Unit Vectors

statement.p: Using \vec A = A_x \hat i + A_y \hat j + A_z \hat k, prove that \vec A \cdot \vec A = A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2.

solution.p:
We display the calculation for x in detail and infer those for y and z from the symmetry.
\vec A \cdot \vec A \amp =(A_x \hat i + A_y \hat j + A_z \hat k)\cdot (A_x \hat i + A_y \hat j + A_z \hat k) \amp = A_x \left( A_x \hat i\cdot \hat i + A_y \hat i \cdot \hat j + A_z \hat i \cdot \hat k \right) + (x \rightarrow y) + (x \rightarrow z) \amp = A_x \left( A_x \times 1 + A_y \times 0 + A_z \times 0 \right) + (x \rightarrow y) + (x \rightarrow z) \amp = A_x^2 + (x \rightarrow y) + (x \rightarrow z) \amp = A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2.
